explanations.A: 1 liter = 1000ml. Therefore, 500ml = (500÷1000) liters = 0.5 liters. Adding this to 1.8 liters: 1.8 + 0.5 = 2.3 liters.
explanations.B: This is the correct answer in milliliters, now convert this into liters.
explanations.C: Before you can add the two quantities together, they must have the same units. Convert 500ml to liters and then you can add it to 1.8 liters.
explanations.D: I think you've tried to convert 1.8 liters to milliliters by dividing 1.8 by 1000. But, 1 liter = 1000ml. Therefore, we convert from liters to milliliters by multiplying by 1000.

explanations.A: 1 liter = 1000ml. Therefore, half a liter = half of 1000ml = 500ml of PVA. For every 100ml of PVA we need 3 teaspoons of bicarb. Therefore, 500ml of PVA needs 5 x 3 = 15 teaspoons. Each teaspoon has a mass of 10g so the total mass of bicarb = 15 x 10 = 150g.
explanations.B: I think you've calculated the number of teaspoons of bicarb. Each teaspoon of bicarb has a mass of 10g, so what is the mass of 15 teaspoons of bicarb?
explanations.C: When converting the number of teaspoons of bicarb to the mass of bicarb in grams, I think you divided the number of teaspoons by 10. But every teaspoon of bicarb has a mass of 10g, so this will be a multiplication calculation.
explanations.D: I think you've calculated the mass of 1 teaspoon of bicarb for every 100ml of PVA. But, the correct ratio is 3 teaspoons of bicarb for every 100ml of PVA.

explanations.A: I think you've assumed that 6 liters only fills 1/4 of the container. But 6 liters fills 3/4 of the container, so 2 liters fills 1/4 of the container. How many liters does the full container hold?
explanations.B: We're told that 6 liters fills 3/4 of the container. So, when the container is full, it can hold (6÷3x4) liters = 8 litres. 1 liter = 1000ml. So, 8 liters = (8 x 1000)ml = 8000ml. 8000ml can fill (8000÷200) cups = 40 cups.
explanations.C: Not quite. We're told that 6 liters fills 3 quarters of the container. So, 1 quarter will hold 6 ÷ 3 = 2 litres. Therefore, how many liters can the whole container hold?
explanations.D: I think you've tried to convert litres to milliliters by multiplying by 100. But, 1 liter = 1000ml. Therefore, we convert from litres to milliliters by multiplying by 1000.

explanations.A: You have calculated as if the whole container holds 8l, but that is only 2/3 of the container. Can you find how much is in 1/3, then use that to find the whole container and how many cups it fills?
explanations.C: Not quite. We're told that 8 liters fills two thirds of the container, not one third. So, one third will hold 8 ÷ 2 = 4 liters. Therefore, how many liters can the whole container hold? And how many cups will this fill?
explanations.D: We're told that 8 liters fills 2/3 of the container. So, when the container is full, it can hold (8÷2x3) liters = 12 liters. 1 liter = 1000ml. So, 12 liters = (12 x 1000)ml = 12000ml. 12000ml can fill (12000÷600) cups = 20 cups.
